Despite this protection [his]309-a rather undersized englishman face was brown exceedingly , and faintly wrinkled through sheer exposure to sun - bright , sun - dried air . The fact enhanced the monkey type of [his]309-a rather undersized englishman features , and made [his]309-a rather undersized englishman clear , light - blue eyes -- so set that they were shadowless below and cavernous above -- look quite aggressively cool , inquisitive , intelligent . Here , the three elements , earth , air , water , lay across the view in three broad bands of blue , curiously similar in tint ; for the sky was pale with excess of light , [the hills]343-the hills with excess of heat , and the water paler than either by reason of a white silt which it brought with it from the snows ; a white silt which a recent flood had left in a fine film upon the sand stretches that showed here and there in [the broad basin]344-the broad basin . "[68-lance] " So am [I]71-vincent , "[71-vincent] said [Vincent Dering]71-vincent quickly . " [I]71-vincent mean [a Catholic]3461-a catholic -- at least [[my]71-vincent people]3462-my people are . [I]71-vincent was talking about [him]3453-that old chap at [the Club]3464-the club , when [I]71-vincent knew [I]71-vincent was coming [here]3395-here , and [Father Delamere]83-delamere was indignant at the idea -- said [he]3453-that old chap was a disgrace to [his]83-delamere cloth . "[71-vincent] [George Dillon]69-dr. dillon 's dry face grew dryer . " Did [he]3453-that old chap , indeed ! [I]69-dr. dillon quite agree that [he]3453-that old chap is , but [I]69-dr. dillon did n't think [Delamere]83-delamere would have admitted the fact [himself]83-delamere ! " Bless [the man]3467-the man , "[69-dr. dillon] [he]69-dr. dillon continued , and the dry voice grew soft , " [he]3467-the man thinks [he]3467-the man knows more about doctoring than [I]69-dr. dillon do , and the worst of it is-- "[69-dr. dillon] here a perfectly charming smile took possession of every wrinkle--"he does , in a way ; for [the natives]3466-the natives believe in [him]3467-the man , and the ' saffron bag ' is the best of all remedies . [You]3469-you see , when [he]3467-the man was younger , [he]3467-the man used often to go with [the pilgrims]3444-the pilgrims and try to pull some of [the poor devils]3471-the poor devils out of the fire -- or rather out of the snow -- for the ' Cradle of [the Gods]3472-the gods ' lies yonder . "[69-dr. dillon] [He]69-dr. dillon pointed to where , faint and far , a peak showed paler than the rest . " Why do n't [they]3444-the pilgrims smear [themselves]3444-the pilgrims here ? "[68-lance] asked [Lance]68-lance stolidly . " Why ? Because [they]3444-the pilgrims do n't . Besides , there is n't much to come and go upon for a robe of righteousness here . Look ! the breeze is blowing it away already ! "[68-lance] In truth the sun , which with the other three elements of earth , and air , and water , give [us]345-us , in all religions , the whole spiritual life of man,--the world of [his]69-dr. dillon probation , the heaven of [his]69-dr. dillon hopes , the means of [his]69-dr. dillon purification , and the fire of [his]69-dr. dillon retribution -- had scorched the fine film to dust , and the wind , blowing where it listed , was sweeping it away , leaving the sand stretches unregenerate as ever . So , through the sun - bright , sun - dried air , while [George Dillon]69-dr. dillon walked back to [[his]69-dr. dillon fifteen hundred malefactors]351-his fifteen hundred malefactors , the little trail of spear - points and bayonets , [men]312-men and [horses]353-horses , drifted at a foot - pace across [the frail bridge]354-the frail bridge towards [the town]331-the town ; drifted unsteadily , [the yielding boats]356-the yielding boats swaying , the wooden girders giving and groaning over [their]357-their burden . Seen so , with but a plank between it and [the milky water]358-the milky water creased by the faint current , there was something unreal in the gay troop of colour and glitter making its way to [the quaint , storeyed town]359-the quaint , storeyed town , ablaze in the sunlight , which turned [each golden temple - spike]360-each golden temple - spike to a star . A cool breeze fluttered the lance - pennants , and brought that faint film of white to horse and [man]361-man , warm flesh , and cold steel . And far away on that pale peak , a little white cloud had rested , hiding the " Cradle of [the Gods]3472-the gods . "[68-lance] [They]371-they were emerging on [a wide , square courtyard of which [the palace]3477-the palace]379-a wide , square courtyard of which the palace formed one side , [the fort another]381-the fort another , a flight of steps leading down to [the river]333-the river a third , while [the fourth]383-the fourth was apparently , [a wing of [the palace]3477-the palace]384-a wing of the palace . "[71-vincent] " [Huzoor]90-huzoor , "[95-the mahomedan] assented [the Mahomedan]95-the mahomedan once more , this time joyfully , as -- a decorous two paces behind -- [his]95-the mahomedan spurs jingled in harmony with [[his]95-the mahomedan captain]394-his captain 's across the raised union - jack towards the river - end of [the courtyard]386-the courtyard where , in a projecting bastion right upon [the bathing steps]396-the bathing steps , the low arched door stood which gave access to [the Fort]3493-the fort . In order to reach [it]398-it [they]399-they had to pass [the solitary visible occupant of [the wide , sunlit courtyard]401-the wide , sunlit courtyard]400-the solitary visible occupant of the wide , sunlit courtyard . This was [a man -- of what rank , education , occupation]402-a man -- of what rank , education , occupation , [none]403-none could tell -- who having raised a square of two - inch - high mud wall between [his]95-the mahomedan twice - born purity and [the world]404-the world , was preparing [his]95-the mahomedan daily food . Naked , save for [his]95-the mahomedan waistcloth , and the thread of [the twice - born]405-the twice - born over [his]95-the mahomedan left shoulder , [he]95-the mahomedan was isolated even from [his]95-the mahomedan kindred . Alone with [himself]95-the mahomedan and [[his]95-the mahomedan God]406-his god . Before [him]95-the mahomedan in [the mud - plastered square]407-the mud - plastered square , as [he]95-the mahomedan sat immovable , was the mud fireplace on which [his]95-the mahomedan wheaten dough - cake was cooking ; beside [him]95-the mahomedan was a leaf - platter of curds , a brass vessel of milk ; a sight to be seen a hundred times a day in [India]8-india ; one which should never be forgotten . The noon was almost shadowless ; yet , even so , as [he]95-the mahomedan led the way , [Captain Dering]71-vincent , from sheer habit , swerved to step further from [the sacred square]408-the sacred square . Doing so [his]95-the mahomedan foot slipped an instant on the lower step . [He]95-the mahomedan gave an impatient exclamation and passed on . A minute later the door of [the fort]3493-the fort clanged behind [the little party]410-the little party , cutting short an English laugh . Then , not till then , [the man in [that square of purity]412-that square of purity]411-the man in that square of purity showed signs of life . [He]95-the mahomedan rose quietly , almost unconcernedly , took the half - baked cake from the embers , the leaf - platter of curds , the vessel of milk , and going down to [the river]333-the river 's edge , flung [his]95-the mahomedan dinner into it , to feed the fishes . In that stumble , the plume - like fringe of [Vincent Dering]71-vincent 's high peaked turban had sent a shadow to overtop the two - inch barrier between [one man]414-one man and [[his]414-one man fellows]415-his fellows . [The garden of [the old palace at [Eshwara]1-eshwara]417-the old palace at eshwara]416-the garden of the old palace at eshwara had been rightly described by [Roshan Khân]89-roshan as [a pleasant place]418-a pleasant place . Longer than [it]416-the garden of the old palace at eshwara was broad , [its]416-the garden of the old palace at eshwara shady walks and orange groves clung to [the river]333-the river , raised above [it]416-the garden of the old palace at eshwara by a balconied wall against which the current ran dimpling . On [two of the remaining sides]420-two of the remaining sides , a twenty - feet high barrier of sheer masonry , buttressed and bastioned , blocked out all curious eyes . On the third , separating [it]416-the garden of the old palace at eshwara from [the courtyard where the big gun stood]421-the courtyard where the big gun stood , rose [the palace]3477-the palace . Seen thus intimately from within , the latter had changed [its]416-the garden of the old palace at eshwara character . No longer severe , stern , giving a blank stare at [the world]404-the world from the narrow slits of infrequent windows , [it]416-the garden of the old palace at eshwara had grown fanciful , almost fantastic , full of canopied turrets and inconsequent little latticed retreats . At least in [the two upper storeys]424-the two upper storeys ; for [the lower one]425-the lower one was more solid , [its]425-the lower one chief feature being [a wide , aisled passage]426-a wide , aisled passage leading right through [it]425-the lower one to a door which gave on [the courtyard]386-the courtyard . Being exactly opposite the one in [the corner of [the Fort bastion on the other side]429-the fort bastion on the other side]428-the corner of the fort bastion on the other side , this door opened , as the latter did , on one of the slantwise limbs of the quaint union - jack of raised paths which centred in [the cannon]430-the cannon . It was not necessary , however , to go round by this in crossing from one door to the other , as by keeping to the river steps , [you]431-you could do so on the same level . In old times [the guardians of the frail beauties for whose delectation [the garden]433-the garden had been made]432-the guardians of the frail beauties for whose delectation the garden had been made , had lived in [the crypt - like vaulted rooms which opened out from [this aisled passage]435-this aisled passage]434-the crypt - like vaulted rooms which opened out from this aisled passage ; so keeping the gate against illegal wanderings . Since the only other exit from [the garden]433-the garden , save by [boat]437-boat , was through [the second storey of [the women]3507-the women 's apartments]438-the second storey of the women 's apartments , and as this was by a door leading directly into [the royal rooms]440-the royal rooms ( which were on the other side of [the tunnel that gave access to [the courtyard]386-the courtyard]441-the tunnel that gave access to the courtyard , and also divided [the palace]3477-the palace into two portions -- male , and female ) , [the butterfly prisoners]444-the butterfly prisoners had had no chance of fluttering to strange honey . In those days , therefore , the door had always been bolted and barred . [It]445-it stood wide open , however , showing a vista of green at the farther end of [the passage]446-the passage , when [Captain Dering]71-vincent and [Lance Carlyon]68-lance came over to [it]445-it in reply to the intimation that [Miss Laila Bonaventura]86-laila was " At [Home]3521-home for music on Wednesday afternoons , "[448-an old pantaloon] which had been brought to [the Fort]3493-the fort overnight by [an old pantaloon]448-an old pantaloon . [A very old pantaloon with a wizened face]449-a very old pantaloon with a wizened face , a few sparse hairs -- dyed flaming red -- standing at right angles to [his]448-an old pantaloon cheeks , and a marvellous livery , consisting for the most part of yards upon yards of tarnished tinsel cloth , twisted and twined about head and waist like [Saturn]97-saturn 's rings . [The oldest of old pantaloons , with a back curved by a life - time of obeisances , a toothless mouth , still full of sonorous titles]450-the oldest of old pantaloons , with a back curved by a life - time of obeisances , a toothless mouth , still full of sonorous titles , and a wicked old eye , watchful for the least want of [the master]451-the master , be it good or evil . [A pantaloon]452-a pantaloon , with [Heaven]78-heaven knows what history of unutterable things hidden in [his]448-an old pantaloon old brain , such as is to be seen , even in these days , lingering round [the ruins of [a native court]454-a native court]453-the ruins of a native court ; [a figure despicable enough , yet real]455-a figure despicable enough , yet real ; so in a way pathetic , by reason of its absolute lack of real interest in things as they are . And now as [the two Englishmen]456-the two englishmen paused,--partly because the swift change from the glare without to the gloom within was [startling,--this same pantaloon]457-startling,--this same pantaloon , with a white muslin robe superadded to the livery as a badge of [his]448-an old pantaloon dignity as [door - keeper]458-door - keeper , precipitated [himself]448-an old pantaloon upon [them]456-the two englishmen from the shadows , with ancient skips of alacrity and loop - like salaams ; then [with crab - like sidlings]459-with crab - like sidlings led the way , [the young men]460-the young men following . " [I]71-vincent must have that old chap on paper before [I]71-vincent leave , "[71-vincent] said [Vincent Dering]71-vincent ; " [he]448-an old pantaloon 's too good to be lost . "[71-vincent] So , [their]456-the two englishmen steps echoing cheerfully with [their]456-the two englishmen laughter , [they]456-the two englishmen went on until , towards the middle of [the passage]446-the passage , [the aisle to [their]456-the two englishmen left]462-the aisle to their left widened , and through a maze of pillars and arches , a glimpse or two of air and sunlight showed sharply . [Lance]68-lance took a curious step towards [them]456-the two englishmen . " Opens on to [the river]333-the river , [I]68-lance expect ; jolly cool it must be in the hot weather ! By Jove ! [those old sinners]3523-those old sinners knew how to be comfortable . [Hullo!"--he]98-hullo!"--he[68-lance] paused in a sort of horror--"I say , [Dering]71-vincent ! [I]68-lance believe it 's [a chapel]3524-a chapel . Yes ! it is ! "[68-lance] [He]68-lance took off [his]68-lance cap instinctively , and moved another step forward to see better . But [Captain Dering]71-vincent called impatiently , " Oh , come along , do , [Carlyon]68-lance ! [I]71-vincent did n't promise to go to [church]3525-church ! Hymns are bad enough in all conscience . "[71-vincent] [Lance]68-lance , however , stood rooted to the spot , cap in hand . " Hush ! "[68-lance] [he]68-lance said in a low voice , " [I]68-lance believe [they]3523-those old sinners are having service . "[68-lance] As [he]68-lance spoke [a robed figure]463-a robed figure showed between the arches against the sunlight beyond [them]456-the two englishmen ; showed with something in its lifted hands , then passed to some unseen altar . " Oh , come along , do ! there 's [a good chap]3526-a good chap , and let ['s]3527-'s get out of the way , "[71-vincent] repeated [Captain Dering]71-vincent , sharply . " It 's [Father Narâyan]80-father narâyan , [I]71-vincent suppose,--he 's as mad as [a hatter]3528-a hatter , and boshes the whole business -- at least , so [Delamere]83-delamere said . [I]71-vincent told [you]68-lance [we]3527-'s were a bit early , but [you]68-lance would start ; still it 's too bad of [the old man]3483-the old man to have [[his]3483-the old man chapel]3511-his chapel in [the front hall]3531-the front hall ! Come along ! and let [us]3527-'s wait in [the garden]433-the garden -- [it]433-the garden looks an awfully jolly one -- awfully-- "[71-vincent] [He]71-vincent paused , perhaps at the change , this time , from gloom to glare , perhaps at the sudden sense of anticipation , the sudden quickening of the pulse of life , which made [him]71-vincent draw a long breath involuntarily . It was not unfamiliar to [him]71-vincent , that sudden stir of vitality , of expectation ; and with a curious smile on [his]71-vincent face [he]71-vincent crossed to the edge of the marble plinth on which [the passage]446-the passage opened , and leaning over the balustrade , looked down to [a terrace below]465-a terrace below , and so on to [the garden]433-the garden itself . A perfect wilderness of common flowers , sown broadcast , lay at [his]71-vincent feet , hemming in a shallow marble tank , which was nearly covered with the dewy leaf - cups of the lotus , and set round with mosaic arabesques . From [this tank]467-this tank [two aqueducts]468-two aqueducts led to the edge of [the terrace]469-the terrace , and ended in steep slopes of fretted marble , where cascades had once wimpled and dimpled down to the water - maze which lay below -- [a shiny lake]470-a shiny lake , cobwebbed over by narrow marble paths just wide enough for the bare , flying feet of [a laughing girl]471-a laughing girl . Beyond was scented shade , with glints of water - courses gleaming here and there ; while here and there came a peep of a latticed balcony overhanging [the river]333-the river ; [a balcony just large enough for [a laughing girl]471-a laughing girl and [[her]471-a laughing girl lover]475-her lover]473-a balcony just large enough for a laughing girl and her lover . Yet there was not even a butterfly to be seen hovering over the flowers . All was still , all was silent , until [Vincent Dering]71-vincent 's careless laugh echoed through the stillness , the silence . " Ca n't [you]3533-you imagine it -- all lit up -- [they]3534-they used to put coloured lamps behind the cascades , [I]71-vincent 'm told , and play ' Catch who can ' up and down and all around [the place]3423-the place ! On the whole [I]71-vincent expect [they]3534-they enjoyed [themselves]3534-they -- better than [the type - writing girls of to - day]3536-the type - writing girls of to - day do , for instance . "[68-lance] " Why not ? For [Captain Vincent Dering]71-vincent 's taste had remained constant for the last three years to a different type of beauty ; a type which , for the first time in [his]71-vincent life , had made [him]71-vincent sentimental , romantic , more or less unselfish . Still [the girl]481-the girl was handsome , even in that babyish frock of starched white muslin , girt about with a yellow silk sash . The dress , [he]71-vincent told himself,--for [he]71-vincent was [a connoisseur in chiffons]482-a connoisseur in chiffons , and had a pretty turn for painting in addition -- would have been better soft , and creamy ; but thank heaven ! the sash was not blue , like the marker of the missal [she]481-the girl carried in [her]481-the girl hand . It might have been ; for it was impossible to fathom the lack of all sense of fitness in [some women]483-some women . Yet the result would have been to take all the ivory tints from [this girl]484-this girl 's complexion , and leave it jaundiced . And the ivory was charming . The figure which came slowly towards [them]499-them was that of [a very old man]500-a very old man , yet one older , by many years , than [his]500-a very old man looks . For [he]500-a very old man was still straight , save for a slight stoop in the neck ; but this , by the backward poise of the head thus made necessary to enable [his]500-a very old man brown eyes to meet all things , after [their]499-them habit , squarely , if softly , gave [him]500-a very old man an air of alertness . ' [I]527-i shall die , [Miss - sahib]3606-miss - sahib , [I]527-i shall surely die , ' [she]3600-a dead girl said to [me]527-i the very last time [I]527-i saw [her]3600-a dead girl ; so [I]527-i promised -- [I]527-i am [a medical missionary]3607-a medical missionary , [Mr. Carlyon]106-mr. carlyon . But when the time came , [they]3608-they would not let [me]527-i in . [I]527-i -- [I]527-i went to [the husband]3609-the husband -- [he]3609-the husband is [an educated man]3604-an educated man -- [you]3611-you may have heard of [him]3609-the husband -- [Rama - nund]108-rama - nund , [a great speaker,--he]3612-a great speaker,--he writes , too , and all that -- but [he]3609-the husband said [he]3609-the husband was helpless with [the women]3507-the women ; and [I]527-i am not sure either if [he]3609-the husband wished it [himself]3609-the husband -- [they]3507-the women do n't know [their]3507-the women own minds . [So poor little Premi]107-poor little premi and [[her]527-i baby]3614-her baby -- Oh ! "[527-i] [she]527-i broke off with an infinite pain in [her]527-i voice--"it is so hard -- so hard for [both]3615-both . "[527-i] [Her]527-i face , set riverwards , was soft , yet stern ; full of fight , yet full of pity , and [Lance]68-lance thought of [a virgin martyr]528-a virgin martyr in the illustrated ' Lives of [the Saints]529-the saints ' with which [[his]68-lance grandmother]530-his grandmother , [Lady Carewe]82-old lady carewe , had been wo nt to still [his]68-lance boyish unrest on Sunday afternoons . Yet there was something beyond that self - concentrated devotion in this face ; something that took [him]68-lance back further still to the days when [he]68-lance had sobbed out [his]68-lance childish hurts in [[his]68-lance mother]531-his mother 's arms . " [She]527-i was ill all yesterday and the day before -- [they]3616-they told [me]531-his mother there was no hope of either -- [they]3616-they just let [them]3616-they die . And [they]3616-they always put [them]3616-they in [the river]333-the river -- [they]3616-they have iron rings round [their]3616-they wrists and ankles to prevent [them]3616-they coming back to harm [the men--]3618-the men-- "[531-his mother] [She]531-his mother paused and turned to [Lance]68-lance swiftly . " Is n't it true that there are not enough of [us]532-these two -- that [we]532-these two want [more women]3619-more women to teach [them]3619-more women what-- "[531-his mother] " But [I]531-his mother does ! "[531-his mother] It was [little Gladys Smith]109-gladys , who , clasping both [Dr. Dillon]69-dr. dillon 's hands in [hers]109-gladys , had swung [herself]109-gladys back from [him]68-lance so as to toss [her]109-gladys fair curls from [her]109-gladys laughing face , as [she]109-gladys looked up at [him]68-lance mutinously . Met and parted hastily ; but not before [the girl with the yellow silk sash]535-the girl with the yellow silk sash , who stood between [them]532-these two , had looked from one to the other with a dim surprise unclosing [her]535-the girl with the yellow silk sash red lips , and showing the gleam of [her]535-the girl with the yellow silk sash white teeth between them . " Who was it , [Khân]110-akbar - jee ? "[81-father ninian] asked [Father Ninian]81-father ninian , in a curiously even tone ; one which , nevertheless , seemed a compelling one , for a murmured name came rapidly , followed by eager explanations . [Father Ninian]81-father ninian frowned , and deliberately put on the gold pince - nez which always hung around [his]81-father ninian neck . [He]81-father ninian seldom used it , however , being , [he]81-father ninian would say playfully , in [[his]81-father ninian native Scotch]545-his native scotch , too " well acquaint "[81-father ninian] with [Eshwara]1-eshwara and all in it to need such help after fifty years experience . So it had come to be an unfailing sign that [he]81-father ninian was face to face with something unexpected , something new . Naturally , therefore , it changed the character of [his]81-father ninian face , bringing back to it a strange look of youth ; of hope and energy -- the look of choice which age has not . " [Roshan Khân]89-roshan , "[81-father ninian] [he]81-father ninian echoed , " why comes [he]89-roshan here ? "[81-father ninian] " The best [I]68-lance have ever come across , "[68-lance] put in [Lance Carlyon]68-lance . " [I]81-father ninian taught [him]89-roshan ; but as [Esmond]112-esmond said of [the botte de Jesuit]3640-the botte de jesuit -- not all . [We]3641-our craftsmen keep something up [our]3641-our sleeve for [our]3641-our own use ! "[81-father ninian] [Lance Carlyon]68-lance 's face grew eager . "[81-father ninian] [The girl]481-the girl walked stolidly to the piano . " What shall [I]481-the girl sing , [guardian]3576-guardian ? "[481-the girl] [she]481-the girl asked . " Sing ? Something hath taken [me]81-father ninian back to the old days -- and sing it well . "[81-father ninian] Something in the pose of [the girl]481-the girl , something in the faint defiance of [her]481-the girl face as [she]481-the girl stood turning over the leaves of the music , attracted [Vincent Dering]71-vincent 's fancy .
